Review Silica functionalized propyl sulfonic acid (SiO2-Pr-SO3H): An efficient catalyst in organic reactions Parisa Gholamzadeh a Ghodsi Mohammadi Ziarani a ⁎ Negar Lashgari b Alireza Badiei b Paria Asadiatouei a a Department of Chemistry, Alzahra University, Vanak Square, P.O. Tel.: +98 2188044040; fax: +98 2188035187. Graphical abstract Silica gel as an accessible substrate with high surface area can be modified by propyl sulfonic acid. Silica-functionalized sulfonic acid (SiO2-Pr-SO3H) as a highly efficient heterogeneous solid acid catalyst catalyzes various organic reactions and can be removed easily, recovered and reused without significant loss of activity. In this review, preparation and application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in organic synthesis is investigated. Keywords Silica-functionalized sulfonic acid SiO2-Pr-SO3H Heterogeneous catalyst Solid acid catalyst 1 Introduction The catalysts generally can be classified into two groups: homogeneous [1] and heterogeneous catalysts [2]. Homogeneous acid catalysts such as HF, HCl and H2SO4 are widely used in many important industrial processes but they have some disadvantages in handling, corrosiveness, trouble work-up procedures and production of toxic waste [3]. Hence, heterogeneous acid catalysts such as perfluorinated ion exchange polymers and Nafion [4,5] were prepared by chemists to solve these problems [6]. Afterwards, solid acid zeoilte [7] and solid superacid sulfated zirconia [8] were synthesized and investigated in this area. It was observed that the utility of heterogeneous solid acid catalysts was improved using high surface area materials [9]. In these catalysts transportation of the reactants to the active sites of the catalyst is unlimited which results in significant effect over the reaction rates. Most of the novel solid acid catalysts are based on silica supports as they have excellent stability (chemical and thermal), high surface area and good accessibility of reactive centers. The fact that organic moieties can be anchored to the surface of silica makes these materials efficient candidates to provide organic–inorganic hybrid materials [10,11]. Mobil Crystalline Material (MCM) and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) are two examples of the first silica materials that were modified by various functional groups [12–15]. Silica gel due to its high surface area (around 800m2/g), high thermal stability and many reactive sites for fuctionalization is an accessible substrate for modification with acidic organic functional groups [16]. In this regard, silica functionalized sulfonic acid was used as an efficient solid acid catalyst that can be easily removed from the reaction mixture and also recovered and reused for several times without significant loss of reactivity [17]. Hence, the focus of this review is on the preparation of sulfonic acid functionalized silica and its role as a solid acid catalyst in various organic reactions. 2 Preparation and surface analyzing of SiO2-Pr-SO3H There are three methods for functionalization of silicas with propyl sulfonic acid which are post-synthesis or grafting, direct synthesis or co-condensation and in situ oxidation method. In grafting method, organosilanes RSi(OR′)3, silazanes HN(SiR3)2 and/or chlorosilanes ClSiR3 react with free silanol groups of silica surface. However, in co-condensation process, tetraalkoxysilanes (RO)4Si react with terminal trialkoxyorganosilanes (R′O)3SiR. 2.1 Post-synthetic functionalization of amorphous silica (grafting) In this method, the calcined SiO2 in dry toluene was refluxed with (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (MPTS) for 24h. Then, the thiol groups of the product were oxidized to sulfonic acid using hydrogen peroxide and one drop H2SO4 in methanol (20ml) for 24h at room temperature. The mixture then was filtered and washed with H2O and acetone to obtain SiO2-Pr-SO3H catalyst [16] (Fig. 1 ). Since silica is an available material, this method has the lowest cost in comparison with other methods. Nevertheless, non-homogeneous distribution of the organic groups on the surface and also closure of some pores, are its disadvantages [18]. 2.2 Direct synthesis (co-condensation) According to this method, a mixture of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and ethanol was stirred; then, 5ml of acetic acid aqueous solution at pH 5 was added to the mixture followed by MPTMS addition to obtain 5%, 10%, 20% loading. After completion of the reaction, solvent was evaporated; the solid was dried and then oxidized by the same procedure described before (Fig. 2 ) [19]. Since the organic groups are direct components of the silica matrix, pore blocking is not a problem in co-condensation method. Also, these groups have homogeneous distribution on the surface. However, the content of organic groups in the modified silica does not normally exceed 40mol% [18]. 2.3 In situ oxidation method (sol–gel technique) As described for co-condensation method except that MPTMS and hydrogen peroxide (33% w/v solid:liquid ratio of 1:18) were added at the same time. The solution was heated up to 80°C and left at this temperature until formation of the gel; and then, it was dried to obtain pure SiO2-Pr-SO3H (Fig. 3 ) [20]. 2.4 Characterization of silica functionalized with propyl sulfonic acid The catalyst surface can be analyzed by different methods such as Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) (Table 1 ), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Chart 1 ) and CHN methods which demonstrated that the organic groups (propyl sulfonic acid) were immobilized into the pores. Pore volume and average pore diameter of SiO2-Pr-SO3H are smaller than those of SiO2 due to the immobilization of organic groups into the pores. The pore size distribution for all the materials is rather broad, centered in the mesoporous range of 3–5nm. As shown BET analyzing in Table 1, Pore volumes in all samples, decreased with the increase of MPTMS loading, indicative of some structure modification. The in situ oxidation samples, in spite of the high surface area and independently on the group loading, have quite lower pore volumes as compared to bare silica [19]. The TGA of SiO2-Pr-SO3H shows two decomposition stages (Chart 1): the first one is below 100°C (4% weight loss), assigned to water loss, and the second is between 100 and 550°C (16% weight loss), assigned to the decomposition of organic groups (Pr-SO3H) anchored on the silica surface and the water loss during the condensation of silanol to siloxane groups [16]. Testa et al. determined acid capacity and concentration of sulfonic groups of samples by titration with 0.01M NaOH. They investigated acidity differences in grafted and co-condensated silicas. In this experiment, 0.1g of solid was added to 10ml of 0.2M NaCl solution as exchange agent. After equilibration of the solution, it was titrated potentiometrically by dropwise addition of 0.01M NaOH solution. As shown in Table 2 , the acid capacity of sulfonic silica materials is based on mmol H+ g−1. Grafting and co-condensation procedures have a lower amount of sulfonic acid groups in the silica, while in situ oxidation gives values more than the other methods and expected values. On the contrary, the hydrogen capacity of the in situ oxidation sample is quite higher than the sulfur amount. Maybe, this is because of an increased acidity of the silica and formation of hydrogen bonds between adjacent acid pair [19]. 3 Application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H as an efficient catalyst in organic reactions 3.1 Protection of organic functional groups 3.1.1 Protection and deprotection of alcohols Application of trimethylsilyl ethers as alcohol protecting groups was first reported by E. J. Corey in 1972 [21]. It was observed that tert-butyldimethylsilyloxy (TBDMS) group is more hydrolytically stable than trimethylsilylether and was used for the first time as alcohols protecting agent in the presence of imidazole. Corey also discovered a rapid cleavage method of the silyl ethers to alcohols using tetra-n-butylammonium fluoride (TBAF) in THF at 25°C. However, fluoride based protocols have some disadvantages such as high cost of the reagent and this fact that some substrates are sensitive to the fluoride ions as a basic ion, which can cause side reactions [22]. Karimi and Zareyee used the sulfonic acid functionalized nanoporous silica for the deprotection and protection of alcohols. In this study, tert-butyldimethylsilyl ethers 1 were deprotected to corresponding alcohols 2 in methanol at 35°C in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H (Scheme 1 ) [23]. As shown in Table 3 , many mild reagents were used for this aimed, e.g. trifluoromethanesulfonic acid trimethylsilylester (TMSOTf) [24], trimethylsilyl chloride (TMSCl) [25], BF3·OEt2 [26], LiCl [27], Sc(OTf)3 [28], InCl3 [29] and ZnBr2 [30]. The role of SiO2-Pr-SO3H as catalyst is more efficient than the others. However, this protocol is the first example of deprotection of TBDMS ethers in which the catalyst can be recovered and reused without considerable loss of reactivity. Silylation of these alcohols was also performed by this group using hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) in dichloromethane to give the corresponding silyl ethers 3 in good yields [31]. Similarly, the alcohols 2 were converted to the corresponding tetrahydropyranyl (THP) ethers 4 in almost quantitative yields [32]. In a related study, Shimizu and coworkers used SiO2-Pr-SO3H in this protection reaction using tetrahydropyran 5 in dichloromethane at room temperature and good to high yields of the corresponding products 6 were obtained (Scheme 2 ). Since the double bond of d-citroneral did not undergo isomerization during acetal formation, the reaction conditions are mild and not sufficiently acidic to cause side-reactions. After the first run, reusability of the catalyst was tested as explained here. It was separated from the reaction mixture by a simple centrifugation, and then washed with CH2Cl2 and dried in vacuum at 298K. The recovered catalyst catalyzed the reaction at least three times keeping good yields without any reactivation-treatment [33]. In the literature survey, a variety of reagents have been introduced for tetrahydropyranyl protection of alcohols such as pyridinium p-toluenesulfonate (PPTS) [34], (CH3)3SiI [35], [Ru(CH3)3(triphos)](OTf)2 [36], CuCl2 [37], DDQ [38], I2 under microwave irradiation [39], ZrCl4 [40] and Bu4N+Br3 − [41] (Table 4 ). Application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H as the catalyst along with mild condition, simplicity of the procedure and general applicability for primary through tertiary alcohols, offers significant improvements over mentioned methods. 3.1.2 Protection of amino functional groups The tert-butoxycarbonyl (Boc) group is one of the most efficient functionalities for the protection of amines [42]. A facile method for the chemo selective Boc protection of amines 7 has been performed by a treatment with (Boc)2O in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in CH2Cl2 at room temperature. Some of the amines are insoluble in CH2Cl2 so in such cases, a mixture of CH2Cl2–MeCN or MeOH–MeCN was used. This method is general for the preparation of N-Boc derivatives 8 of aliphatic (acyclic and cyclic), aromatic, and heteroaromatic amines; primary and secondary amines; aminols, amino-esters; and sulfonamides (Scheme 3 ) [43]. Different catalysts including I2 [44], LiClO4 [45], ZrCl4 [46], sulfamic acid under ultra sound (US) [47], 1-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate [(HMIm)BF4] [48], NaHCO3 [49], and 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) [50] were used for Boc protection of amines (Table 5 ). 3.1.3 Protection of carbonyl functional groups One of the popular protection methods of carbonyl functional groups is acetalization reaction which can generally be performed using p-TSA, triflic acid, and pyridinium salts. These homogeneous catalysts present limitations due to the use of toxic and corrosive reagents, the tedious work-up procedure, and the necessity of neutralization of the strong acid media producing undesired wastes [42,51]. Dimethyl acetals can be prepared from the reaction of carbonyl compounds with excess methanol catalyzed by various reagents such as HClO4-SiO2 [52]; Gopinath et al. used Bu4NBr3 as catalyst in this reaction to give acetals at room temperature with low to high yields [53]. However, In Procuranti and Connon publication, simple pyridinium salt acted as more efficient catalyst but need one day for completion of the reaction [54]. Shimizu and coworkers performed acetalization of carbonyl functional groups 9 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H with methanol in good to high yields (Scheme 4 ) [33]. It was found that Ce-exchanged clay [55] and siliceous mesoporous silica [56] catalyzed this reaction type of linear aldehydes at room temperature with yields below 34%. In contrast, SiO2-Pr-SO3H catalyzed it with good yields at room temperature. High turnover numbers is another advantage of SiO2-Pr-SO3H that needs very small amount of the catalyst (0.01mol%). 1,3-Dioxolanes 13 and 14 can be easily prepared from the reaction of carbonyl compounds with ethylene glycol in the presence of a Brönsted or a Lewis acid catalyst [42]. This reaction was also performed in the presence of various catalysts including Bu4NBr3 [53], cerium (III) trifluoromethanesulfonate (Ce(OTf)3) [57] and iodobenzene dichloride (PhICl2) [58]. Hydroxyacetophenones were converted into the corresponding ethylene acetals using Ce(OTf)3 in the presence of triisopropyl orthoformate; the solvent was hexane but the reaction needed several hours to complete [57]. In another publication [58], aliphatic and aromatic chloroketones were converted into their corresponding acetals in good to high yields using PhICl2 in the presence of 4Å molecular sieves at room temperature and with the reaction time below 30min, but PhICl2 is not a green catalyst. Therefore, Shylesh et al. used SiO2-Pr-SO3H as a green and efficient catalyst in acetalization reaction of ethylacetoacetate 11 with ethylene glycol 12 to give fructone 13 (Scheme 5 ); after 2h of the run, its selectivity was found to be more than 90% of yields [59]. The silica gel was completely inactive under this reaction conditions but with a 5wt% loading of the SO3H groups, the conversion was increased which confirms that the catalyst has mild acidity. The reusability and stability of the sulphonic acid anchored catalysts was investigated two times and found that after each cycle, the conversion was decreased and it means the relation of sulphonic acid groups leaching to the catalytic activity. The dithioacetal protection of carbonyl groups is a common and popular practice in organic chemistry [42] due to their stability under acidic and basic conditions [60]. Thioacetals are generally prepared by condensation of carbonyl compounds with thiols in the presence of strong acid catalysts such as AlCl3 [61], TiCl4 [62], Vo(OTf)3 [63] and I2 [64]. Although these methods represent useful advantages, but many of them are carried out in anhydrous organic solvents, because Lewis acids used are hygroscopic and easily decompose in the presence of even small amount of water. In an alternative process, Karimi and Khalkhali used SiO2-Pr-SO3H as an efficient catalyst in the dithioacetalizations of a variety of carbonyl compounds 9 and 15 in water (Scheme 6 ) [65]. However, under similar reaction conditions, other carbonyl compounds such as aromatic and sterically hindered ketones remained intact in refluxing water even after several hours. Protection of aldehydes is a frequently used and important method in organic chemistry. One of the aldehyde protection methods is acetalization of carbonyl groups which was performed using acetic anhydride in the presence of many catalysts such as P2O5-montmorilonite K10 [66], silica sulfuric acid [67], copper p-toluenesulfonate [68], [bmim]BF4 as ionic liquid [69], RuCl3 [70] and SO4 −2/SnO2 [71] (Table 6 ). Mohammadi Ziarani et al. reported the preparation of 1,1-diacetates 19 from aromatic aldehydes 15 and acetic anhydride 18 using catalytic amount of SiO2-Pr-SO3H under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 7 ) [72]. The reaction scalability was confirmed using 9mmol of aldehyde and 1.8mL of acetic anhydride in the presence of 0.05g of catalyst; the reaction yield and time were respectively about 95% and 10min. 3.2 Application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in two-component reactions 3.2.1 α-Monobromination of carbonyl compounds N-Bromosuccinamide (NBS), as a superior brominating agent in ease term of handling, is now being used increasingly for α-bromination of carbonyl compounds. NBS was applied for this purpose in the presence of an initiator, e.g. aza-bisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) or dibenzyl peroxide (BPO) [73], Mg(ClO4)2 [74], NH4OAc [75] and NaHSO4 adsorbed on silica gel [76] (Table 7 ). However, the preparation of α-monobrominated compounds as the major products is still a problem. Das et al. have demonstrated that SiO2-Pr-SO3H is an efficient catalyst for α-monobromination of a wide range of carbonyl compounds [77]. As shown in Scheme 8 , this group of researchers used various ketones 20 and α-dicarbonyl compounds 21 to afford the corresponding products 22 and 23 in high yields and short reaction times. 3.2.2 Acetylation reactions Several publications have discussed Friedel–Crafts acylation of anisole in the presence of various catalysts. Large-pore zeolites such as tschernichite (BEA) and faujasite framework (FAU) were employed in the acetylation of anisole, but when the reaction was performed under batch conditions, conversion proceeds were rapidly decreased [78–80]. In a related study, Derouane and coworkers demonstrated the reasons of zeolites deactivation in this reaction [81,82]. Some of other catalysts which were tested in acetylation of anisole include WO3/ZrO2 [83], Ln(OTf)3 [84] and LiClO4–acyl anhydrides complexes [85]. The main products of this reaction are 2- and 4-methoxyacetophenone, usually having better yield of 4-methoxyacetophenone. In this case, the catalytic activity of WO3/ZrO2 found for the acetylation of anisole with 89% conversion to 25, however, both of Ln(OTf)3 and LiClO4 had the conversion up to 99%. Alternatively, Shylesh et al. found that SiO2-Pr-SO3H can be used in acetylation reaction of anisole 24 with acetic anhydride 18 with 100% conversion to the main product 25 (Scheme 9 ) [59]. 3.2.3 Ritter reaction (amide functional group preparation) The amide functional group is one of the most important groups present in lactam and peptide structures which are very important moieties in natural products and drugs activities [86,87]. Ritter reaction [88,89] is a significant method for the synthesis of amide functional groups. Over the years, several procedures have been employed for Ritter reaction in which sulfuric acid was replaced by TfOH, 2,4-dinitrobenzenesulfonic acid (DNBSA) [90], P2O5/SiO2 [91], o-benzenedisulfonamide [92], HClO4-functionalized silica-coated Fe2O3 nanoparticles [93], Bi(OTf)3 [94] and so on (Table 8 ). SiO2-Pr-SO3H was found to be a suitable catalyst in Ritter reaction to prepare amides 27 by the reaction of various nitriles 26 with benzylic, allylic, and tertiary alcohols 2 under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 10 ) [95]. 3.2.4 Friedländer synthesis Friedländer synthesis is one of the classic heterocyclic reactions, in which, o-aminoaryl aldehydes or ketones react with enolizable carbonyl compounds using Brønsted or Lewis acid catalyst [96]. Cravotto and coworkers reported solvent free Friedländer synthesis of quinoline derivatives 29 using o-aminobenzophenones 28 and carbonyl compounds 20 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H under MW irradiation (Scheme 11 ). After performing one reaction under the conditions described, the catalyst was filtered, washed with EtOAc, and then activated at 60°C prior to reuse for a consecutive run under the same reaction conditions. Thus, after the first run, that gave the corresponding quinoline in 90% conversion; the recovered catalyst was subjected to a reaction from which it also gave the quinoline in 87% for first and 85% conversion for the second time. This clearly demonstrates the practical recyclability of this catalyst for this reaction (Table 9 ) [97]. Quinolines are important scaffolds found in a variety of natural products [98,99] and are used in several areas including drug design [100–103], polymers [104] and electronic chips [105–107]. 3.2.5 Synthesis of 2-substituted benzimidazole compounds Das et al. performed an efficient synthesis of 2-substituted benzimidazoles 31 using o-phenylenediamine 30 and substituted aldehydes 15 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H at room temperature (Scheme 12 ) [108]. Benzimidazole moiety is a common feature found in several bioactive molecules such as enviroxime with antiviral activities [109]. Various benzimidazole derivatives were synthesized using carboxylic acids or aldehydes in the presence of a catalysts such as In(OTf)3 [110], alumina-methanesulfonic acid (AMA)/MW [111], H2O2/HCl [112], SnCl2·2H2O/MW [113] and polyphosphoric acid [114] (Table 10 ). When SnCl2·2H2O was used as catalyst, 2-nitroaniline was reduced to phenylenediamine and then reacted with carbonyl compounds to give the products [113]. Based on the results in Table 10, microwave irradiation reduces the reaction time, but without it, SBA-Pr-SO3H has also considerable yields in good reaction times. Although In(OTf)3 shows the best results, but it can be recovered under high pressure for 3h which is unfavorable. 3.3 Application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in multi-components reactions 3.3.1 Synthesis of 1,2-disubstituted benzimidazole compounds 2-Aryl-1-arylmethyl-1H-1,3-benzimidazoles 32 were synthesized in good to excellent yields by pseudo three-component reaction of o-phenylendiamine 30 with two moles of aromatic aldehydes 15 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 13 ) [115]. Although several catalysts such as trifluoroacetic acid [116], metal hydrogen sulfates [117] and Fe(ClO4)3 [118] have been reported for the synthesis of these skeletons, silica-based sulfonic acid promoted methodology has a valuable contribution to the existing processes because of the experimental simplicity, easy work-up procedure, and high product yields. 3.3.2 Synthesis of 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted imidazole compounds SiO2-Pr-SO3H has been used as an efficient catalyst for an improved and rapid synthesis of 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted imidazoles 36 by four-component, one-pot condensation of benzil 33, aryl aldehydes 15, ammonium acetate 34 and substituted aromatic amines 35 in excellent yields under solvent-free condition (Scheme 14 ) [119]. Application of other catalysts such as p-TSA [120], InCl3·3H2O [121], and P2O5/SiO2 [122] was also investigated in this reaction (Table 11 ). 3.3.3 Synthesis of α,α′-bis(substituted benzylidene)cycloalkanone The aromatic aldehydes 15 underwent cross aldol condensation reaction with cyclopentanone and cyclohexanone 20 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H to afford the corresponding α,α′-bis(substituted benzylidene)cyclopentanone or hexanone 37 in good to excellent yields without any side reactions (Scheme 15 ) [16]. This cross aldol condensation reaction was investigated in the presence of various catalysts, e.g. complexes of metal (II) ions [123], RuCl3 [124], Cp2ZrH2 [125], TiCl3(SO3CF3) [126], KF-Al2O3 [127] and LiClO4 [128]. Many other methods can also be found in literature. 3.3.4 Synthesis of β-acetamido ester or ketone compounds β-Acetamido esters are useful building blocks found in various biological and pharmaceutical active compounds such as γ-lactam [129]. Various catalysts such as CoCl2 [130], Mg(HSO4)2 [131], La(OTf)3 [132], and K5CoW12O40·3H2O [133] were employed for the synthesis of these skeletons. However, these protocols suffer from one or more limitations: performing the reaction under special conditions, long reaction times, use of toxic, expensive and or large amounts of the catalyst, difficult work-up procedure and low yields of products. Silica-functionalized sulfonic acid efficiently catalyzed one-pot multi-component condensation reaction of enolizables alkyl acetoacetates 11 or ketones 38 with acetonitrile 39, aryl aldehydes 15 and acetyl chloride to afford the corresponding β-acetamido esters 40 or ketones 41 in excellent yields and in relatively short reaction times (Scheme 16 ) [134]. 3.3.5 Biginelli reaction Paul et al. have developed a mild, simple, and greener reaction for the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidines/thiones 43 using three-component Biginelli reaction of ethylacetoacetate 11 with aromatic aldehydes 15 and urea (or thiourea) 42 in the presence of acid functionalized nanoporous silica as a solid acid catalyst (Scheme 17 ) [135]. The work-up procedure was very simple and Biginelli products were obtained in good to excellent yields. Many other methodology procedures were also developed for dihydropyrimidines Biginelli reactions in the presence of various catalysts such as coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles [136], β-cyclodextrin [137], [Al(H2O)6](BF4)3 [138] and sulfonated carbon [139] and so on. 3.3.6 Synthesis of 1,4-dihydropyridines Hantzsch reaction is the first method for the synthesis of 1,4-dihydropyridines using 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and NH3 [140]. Although numerous modified methods have been reported for Hantzsch reaction [141–144], a cost-effective and solvent-free procedure for the one-pot synthesis of 1,4-dihydropyridines 44 was performed using aldehydes 15, a β-ketoesters 11, and ammonium acetate 34 in the presence of a catalytic amount of SiO2-Pr-SO3H under stirring at 60°C (Scheme 18 ) [145]. However, this method was not suitable for the preparation of N-aryl-1,4-dihydropyridines. Das et al. found that the application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H as catalyst in the three-component reaction of aromatic amines 45, cinnamaldehyde 46, and β-ketoesters 11 affords the corresponding 1,4-dihydropyridines 47 in high yields and short reaction times (Scheme 19 ) [146]. 3.3.7 Synthesis of acridine derivatives Sulfonic acid functionalized silica was found to be an efficient solid acid catalyst in the synthesis of 1,8-dioxo-decahydroacridine derivatives 48 by one-pot pseudo four-component reaction of aromatic aldehydes 15, amines 34 or 35 and dimedone 20 under solvent-free condition (Scheme 20 ) [147]. Some methods are available in the literature for the synthesis of corresponding acridines using different nitrogen sources like ammonium acetate and various anilines [148] along with application of different catalysts such as p-dodecylbenezenesulfonic acid [149] and amberlyst-15 [150]. 3.3.8 Synthesis of octahydroquinolines 2,5-Dioxo-1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8-octahydroquinoline derivatives 50 were synthesized by one-pot reaction of aromatic aldehydes 15, dimedone 20, Meldrum's acid 49 and ammonium acetate 34 in the presence of sulfonic acid functionalized silica under solvent-free condition (Scheme 21 ) [151]. The synthesis of octahydroquinolines was achieved in the presence of various catalysts such as [bmim][BF4] [152] and ZnO [153] and or using microwave irradiation [154]. 3.3.9 Synthesis of pyrimido[4,5-d]pyrimidinones A mild and simple procedure was developed for the one-pot synthesis of compounds 51 by stirring a mixture of aromatic aldehydes 15, urea 42 and aromatic ketones 38 at 80°C using sulfonic acid functionalized silica in the presence of KHSO4 (Scheme 22 ) [155]. Previously, Sedova and Mamaev reported the synthesis of such pyrimido[4,5-d]pyrimidinones with low yields of products [156]. Similarly, Shi et al. synthesized these compounds in the presence of KHSO4 in acetonitrile in shorter reaction times with high yields of products [157]. 3.3.10 Synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[b]pyran derivatives SiO2-Pr-SO3H was used in the synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[b]pyrans 53 by the reaction of appropriated aromatic aldehydes 15, malononitrile 52 and dimedone 20 in refluxing H2O (Scheme 23 ) [158]. Various catalysts such as NaBr under microwave irradiation [159], triethyl benzyl ammonium chloride (TEBA) [160], KF-alumina [161] and organocatalysts [162] were used in this synthesis. The high yield of products and short reaction times demonstrated that sulfonic acid functionalized silica acts efficiently in this reaction. 3.3.11 Synthesis of chromene derivatives Aromatic aldehydes 15, malononitrile 52, and 4-hydroxycoumarin 20 in the presence of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in H2O/EtOH effectively yielded 3,4-dihydropyrano[c]chromene derivatives 54 (Scheme 24 ) [163]. In literature, a few methods have been reported for the synthesis of dihydropyrano[c]chromenes in which various catalysts such as S-proline [164], K2CO3 under microwave irradiation [165], and MgO [166] were used. 3.3.12 Synthesis of xanthene derivatives The eco-friendly and one-pot synthesis of biologically active 14-aryl-14H-dibenzo[a,j]xanthenes 56 has been achieved through the reaction of aryl aldehydes 15 and β-naphthol 55 under solvent-free conditions catalyzed by SiO2-Pr-SO3H (Scheme 25 ) [167]. Other catalysts such as AcOH-H2SO4 [168], p-TSA [169], sulfamic acid [170] and boric acid [171] have also been used for the synthesis of benzoxanthenes (Table 12 ). 3.4 Application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in esterification, transesterification and biofuel production Esters are very important compounds in industries as synthetic flavors because of their pleasant odors. These compounds can be produced by the reaction of an acid with alcohols which is known as Fischer esterification. However, esterification reaction proceeds very slowly in the absence of strong acids. In the presence of catalytic amounts of concentrated H2SO4 or HCl, the reaction reaches equilibrium within a matter of a few hours. Cano-Serrano et al., for the first time, used SiO2-Pr-SO3H in the esterification reaction of acetic acid with methanol in liquid phase. In spite of some sulfur leaching during the oxidation of the thiols, their samples had good catalytic activity in the reaction [172]. Then, Sesta et al. synthesized catalyst samples using three methods which explained before. They used these catalysts in the esterification of equimolar amounts of acetic acid with butanol to give butyl acetate. The alcohol conversion as a function of the various catalysts was summarized in Chart 2 which shows that in situ oxidation method sample has the best catalytic activity in comparison with other samples [19]. Transesterification and esterification are industrially important processes for biodiesel production which is a renewable, biodegradable and non-toxic fuel. Transesterification of triglycerides with methanol gives a mixture of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) that is named as biodiesel [173]. The second generation of biodiesels uses low-grade oil feedstock which has free fatty acids (FFA) contents between 0.5 and 15% and leads to the undesired soap formation. In this case, esterification is necessary to reduce the amount of acids [20]. Formation of glycerol during the production of biodiesel (10wt%) as principal by-product is the other major problem [174]. The esterification of glycerol into acetins is quite attractive because they have many applications as solvent, plasticizers, tinning oils, and hydraulic oils [175]. Triacetin is the most useful acetin which improves the fuel cold and viscosity by its small amounts addition into biodiesel. Testa et al. synthesized different solid acid catalysts, sulfonic acid functionalized amorphous and mesoporous silicas, titania doped silica HMS, sulfated zirconia and niobic acid, and then tested them in the esterification reaction of glycerol. The reactions were carried out in the absence of solvent and with a molar ratio of acetic acid:glycerol corresponding to 3:1 under refluxing at 105°C. The catalytic behavior of materials was evaluated in the terms of glycerol conversion and selectivity toward monoacetylglycerols (MAG), diacetylglycerol (DAG) and triacetylglycerol (TAG) (Table 13 ). The full conversion of glycerol was obtained in the presence SiO2-Pr-SO3H and mesoporous silicas (SSBA) in only 1h with selectivity to the desired TAG of 49% and 33%, respectively [174]. Sulfonic acid-functionalized hybrid silicas, both amorphous and with ordered mesopority of the HMS and SBA-15 type were tested in the transesterification reaction of short chain esters (from hexanoic to lauric ethyl ester). According to the data in Chart 3 , the two more active materials were the functionalized amorphous silica (10% loaded produced by in situ oxidation, 10Am-Ox) and functionalized SBA (10% loaded produced by in situ oxidation, 10SBA-Ox) achieving 63% and 44% yield of methyl ester, respectively. A considerable increase in the conversion was obtained with the catalysts prepared by in situ oxidation method with respect to the grafted ones. Then, recyclability and stability of the catalysts were tested. As shown in Chart 4 , a decreasing level of activity was observed for 10Am-Ox catalyst after the first cycle. By using 10SBA-Ox, the activity in the first cycle, lower with respect to the amorphous catalyst, was maintained almost constant for all the subsequent cycles. Sulfonic groups leaching in amorphous silica explains its higher activity probably linked to a contribution of homogeneous species [20]. 4 Conclusion In summary, we gave an overview on application of silica-functionalized sulfonic acid as an efficient catalyst in organic reactions. Silica-functionalized sulfonic acid (SiO2-Pr-SO3H) with mild acidity has shown excellent activity in various chemical reactions especially organic synthesis. Excellent accessibility, high surface area, high thermal stability and many reactive sites are significant properties of this catalyst. SiO2-Pr-SO3H was proved to be a recyclable, green, and highly effective solid acid catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Silica gel as an accessible substrate with high surface area can be modified by propyl sulfonic acid. Silica-functionalized sulfonic acid (SiO2-Pr-SO3H) as a highly efficient heterogeneous solid acid catalyst catalyzes various organic reactions and can be removed easily, recovered and reused without significant loss of activity. In this review, preparation and application of SiO2-Pr-SO3H in organic synthesis is investigated.
coredata.dc:title: Silica functionalized propyl sulfonic acid (SiO2-Pr-SO3H): An efficient catalyst in organic reactions
